title: Which novel has the biggest plot twist? - Quora

response.answer_text: Image: Brendan Rile | CC BY 2.0 If you don’t mind campy pulp fiction, read Mickey Spillane’s Vengeance is Mine. Part of his Mike Hammer series, this book has Spillane’s trademark machine-gun prose style and a surprise twist at the end that impressed my fourteen-year-old self. I won’t reveal the plot, but there’s this debauched private investigator who usually wakes up with a wicked hangover. He has a fifth of Irish whiskey in the bottom drawer of his desk, and gargles with it to clear his head. Mike Hammer smirks at his own mug in the mirror, saying devil-may-care things like, “It was a hell of a shame I wasn’t handsome.” Hammer has a raven-haired secretary named Velda—she’s a big girl with “million-dollar legs” and no last name—and an office somewhere in Manhattan. He wears a hat and raincoat and has a license to pack the big fat .45 he’s carried since his service in the Pacific Theater in World War II. Mike Hammer is big and tough and mean as a bear with a boil on its ass. He slaps, punches, kicks and head-butts his way through the streets and alleys of New York, dispatching bad guys with practiced panache. When he needs artillery support, that rod is in his fist. He never gets slide bite as he squeezes off rounds, gunning down hoods and commies alike. And when they go down, they stay down: those .45-caliber slugs make holes “big enough to poke your finger through.” Hammer chain-smokes Luckies and flips the butts in rain puddles. He hangs out in bars and slouches in greasy spoon diners. And when he slaps a dime on the counter for a cup of joe, you know what that coffee tastes like. Mickey Spillane sold 200 million books in paperback. He never called the people who bought his books readers. Spillane called them customers, and gave them what they wanted. He wrote his first Mike Hammer novel (I, the Jury) in nine days. Vengeance is Mine was his third book in the series. No one I know reads him today. Renegade private eyes fell off the bestseller charts years ago. But Ayn Rand was a major Mike Hammer fan back in the 1950s, and wrote Spillane a number of fawning letters. Spillane’s gritty fiction was crude, grotesquely over-the-top, misogynistic and politically incorrect. The man wrote like he had Joe McCarthy hissing in his ear about reds under the bed. The Russians were coming for sure. Prejudiced? Sure. He could offend you. On the other hand, Mike Hammer may sound quaint to readers unfazed by zombies and vampires on feeding frenzies. So who knows? He might even amuse you.

I am Legend by Richard Matheson…  Towards the end of the book - the whole story gets turned on its head, making you question everything you’ve read and understood during the story… (I’m not going to divulge the plot here - go and read the book - believe me - it’s worth it). One reason I detested the film version  They completely ignored the whole ‘raison d’etre’ of the film… Why? Because it’s an American film - and the hero has always got to wear a white hat.
